answers.author: Andrew Mair
answers.text:
Now and in my last several CEO or COO positions my employers and I have felt it was most compatible with FLSA practice for exempt employees and fairest to me that I do not earn nor am I charged with leave time.  My leave is at my and my employers' discretion.  Downside to me is that I have no entitlement to cash out unused time.  Upside is access to leave time appropriate to my position without having to wait 20+ years to reach the same eligibilities as rank and file staff.  Comp time solutions easily can run afoul of FLSA if either party becomes disgruntled so I have avoided them.

answers.author: John Garvison
answers.text:
The main problem with giving exempt employee's 'credit time' is that you are now making them into an hourly employee and setting up a potential huge liability for your organization in the future. My organization, had this 'credit time' arrangement prior to my arrival as the CFO. This credit time was given to employees for hours worked in excess of a 40 hour week, which in effect negated their exempt status.
If an employee is classified 'exempt' and truly falls under the guidelines and should be an exempt employee. The assumption is that they will work however long it takes to get the job done, whether that is 30 hours per week or 120 hours per week. The benefit to being exempt is if you take time off in less than full day increments, then typically you do not have to report this as usage of accrued leaves, (this depends based upon your organization's personnel policies and contractual arrangements). But, by allowing 'credit time' it appears you are allowing staff to have the best of both worlds, and incurring a large liability at the employee's time of separation.

answers.author: Tony Brown
answers.text:
Here we distinguish between how employees accrue additional work hours based on their FLSA exempt/nonexempt status. Our nonexempt employees accrue the typical compensable ("comp") time at 1:1.5 for hours above 40 in a week. We allow exempt employee to accrue "Excess" time. Excess time is always accrued at and 1:1 basis for hours above 40 in a week. We call it Excess time so there is not confusion regarding the employee ever being paid ("compensated") for the time. These exempt employees must use their excess time by the end of the next pay period following the accural pay period, otherwise the time is lost. We remind exempt employees that this is a privilege, not a right, that is offered here in Halifax County; the employees have expressed appreciation with this system. As with any accrual of comp/excess time, it has to be preapproved by the employee's supervisor. FYI - My background is in HR and I also implemented this when I worked in a community college district in a previous life; this change was based on a lawsuit directive that we pay a departing "exempt" employee for their additional time because we called it "comp" time. I'll be happy to share our policy if you like.

answers.author: Jay Gsell
answers.text:
We have a few mid level mgrs/salaried e's( county hwy and Parks and Facility Mgnt.  who are still eligible for comp time up to 24-40 hrs which must be used relatively close to the time of accumulation. All top mgrs are no longer keeping time records on non 37.5 /wk hrs and the expectation like other organizations is you work to the extent your presence/skills are needed and there is no set hrs /work wk. We use the honor  system for those non vacation or sick leave accumulations and we still have an annual personal leave allownace for all employees with Mgrs/salaried getting the equiv of three days that can be  used in hrly increments and are attributed on payroll "forms" per bi weekly  pay  periods. it's all about trust and integrity when it comes to Dept heads vs the mgrs they supervise and the use of mgnt time off. We fremind them that the public knows who they are, is always vigilant and can often take things the wrong way when they see our Mgrs out and about during what community norms say is the standard work day.

answers.author: Benjamin Cowan
answers.text:
Our management staff complete monthly timesheets that include what we call "exempt time".  Gains and use of exempt time is tracked, but the below wording from our Personnel Policies has done a good job of preventing abuse:
Exempt employees shall not work less than their established workweek. An exempt employee shall not be
entitled to overtime compensation either in cash or in compensatory time for work in excess of forty (40) hours
per week. It is recognized that the exempt employee is hired to perform specified duties and such other duties
consistent with the job status and that performance of those duties will, at times, require absence from the
office, attendance at night meetings and work in excess of forty (40) hours per week. The exempt employee
shall not be eligible for compensation greater than the established salary. Consequently, exempt employees are
free to organize their work schedule in such a fashion as to accommodate their workload and may flex their
hours as appropriate, provided that an exempt employee shall regularly be present during business hours.

answers.author: Josephine Valencia
answers.text:
When I worked in Durham, NC in addition to "sick" and "vacation" time,  we had a third category of leave known as Manager's Leave.   At the Department Director's discretion, an employee could be awarded up to an additional two weeks of time.  It was tracked like other leave times, but it did not accumulate and was not paid at separation.  The City Manager also could award the time to Department Directors.   The downside was that it was awarded at the beginning of the year, based on the projection of what the Director expected the workload to be for certain employees.   In our Department, it was fairly accurate.  But I'm not sure what happened in other places if employees worked more or less than anticipated.  But in either case, it was meant as a recognition of the long hours that were sometimes required and not meant to be an hour for hour compensation.

text: Like most cities my senior managers are in salary positions and can accumulate and use sick and vacation leave.  Knowing that their duties do not end a 5 pm I am looking for a way to recognize their contribution by allowing time off without requiring the use of vacation.   Does your city provide scheduling that either allows for a certain day off during the week or the accumulation of admin time?
